column1: Registration Update Nov 25, 2016 for Testing Gravity 2017 (89799)

column24: Would you like to contribue a poster?
column25: Would you like to give a contributed talk in a a p
column26: Abstract Title
column27: Abstract Details

column26: LSS probes for Dark Energy & Modified Gravity?
column27: The perturbative treatment of LSS, especially in its effective theory realization, can well describe the quasi-linear regime. I will elaborate on recent progress towards including a dark energy or a modified gravity component in this framework.

column26: Nowhere to hide: Unscreening Chameleons with a Black Hole
column27: It is believed that the additional degrees of freedom in any modification of gravity are screened by the matter densities coexisting in an astrophysical Black Hole. In this talk, we find that this might not always be the case.

column26: Testing local Lorentz invariance with gravitational waves
column27: Following a review of the framework for testing local Lorentz invariance provided by the gravitational Standard-Model Extension, applications to gravitational-wave related searches will be discussed.

column26: Observing GR effect and mass of the massive BH at the center of our galaxy: GR calculation and Subaru telescopce observation
column27: We report our GR calculation and ifra-red observation of a star, so-called S2, orbiting the BH at galactic center.It's expected that, around 2018, BH's GR effect is detected with 10 sigma precision and BH mass is determined with 1 percent accuracy.

column26: Prospects for gravitational wave observations: update from LIGO
column27: Since making the first measurements of gravitational waves in fall of 2016, LIGO scientists have improved the performance of the LIGO detectors. LIGO Hanford observatory has focused on high power operation, while LIGO Livingston Observatory has prima

column26: Testing the equivalence principle with macroscopic atom interferometers
column27: Matter wave interferometers that cover macroscopic scales in space and in time have a high intrinsic sensitivity to inertial forces.  We show how such interferometers can be used in a dual configuration for a test of the weak equivalence principle.

column23: Nathalie DERUELLE and Edward K. PORTER
column26: to be confirmed
Signatures of Horndeski's Gravity on ultra-large cosmic scales

column7: The University of Texas at Dallas
column26: Cosmological consistency tests of gravity theory and cosmic acceleration
column27: Testing general relativity at cosmological scales and probing the cause of cosmic acceleration are among the important objectives targeted by incoming and future astronomical surveys and experiments. I present our recent results on consistency tests

column26: Potential tests of Quantum Gravity
column27: Most quantum gravity theories predict the Generalized Uncertainty Principle (GUP) to replace the Heisenberg principle near the Planck scale. We show that GUP in turn predicts potentially observable quantum gravity effects in quantum optical systems.

column26: Causal structure and shock formation in the most general scalar-tensor theories
column27: We study causal structure and shock formation in Horndeski theory and its generalization to two scalar fields. We find that shock formation may occur for gravitational wave in these theories. (Full abstract sent to testing-gravity-2017@sfu.ca)

column26: Tensor modes produce a scale dependent Non-Gaussianity
column27: Planck 2015 data shows a possible scale dependent local Non-Gaussianity. I will show how such feature is naturally achieved if tensor modes significantly contribute to primordial NG. This is possible in a space-time symmetry breaking theory.

column26: Testing gravity with E_G: Mapping theory onto observation
column27: The cosmological statistic E_G tests gravity by combining weak lensing, galaxy clustering, and redshift-space distortions. I will discuss the impact and mitigation of theoretical uncertainties affecting E_G, and its relevance for future surveys.

column26: Proofs of the cosmological phase transitions
column27: It is expected that the universe had experienced many kinds of phasetransitions. These phase transitions are difficult to observe directly, buttheir relics, called cosmic defects" can be a smoking gun of them.""t is expected that the universe had experienc"

column26: Cosmological constraints on scalar-tensor cosmology and the variation of the gravitational constant
column27: We present cosmological constraints on the scalar-tensor theory of gravity by analyzing the angular power spectrum data of the cosmic microwave background (CMB) obtained from the Planck 2015 results together with the baryon acoustic oscillations (BAO

column26: Wormhole Solutions in Modified Gravity
column27: In this talk, I shall use cut and paste technique in order to construct thin-shell wormhole of a stellar system with f(R) terms. I shall assume f(R) model as a source of exotic content in the wormhole throat.

column26: f(R,DµR,…,Dµ1…DµnR) theories of gravity and the equivalence with scalar-multi-tensorial theories.
column27: f(R,DµR,…,Dµ1…DµnR) theories of gravity are proven to be equivalent to scalar-multi-tensorial theories. This result can be seen as an extension of the equivalence between f(R) and Brans-Dicke theories.

column26: Cosmology with bigravity theory
column27: As an infrared modification of gravity, we discuss dRGT bigravity theory, focusing on if it can consistently explain cosmological evolution both in early time and in late time. We also discuss fluctuations generated during inflation in bigravity.

column26: Nowhere to hide: Unscreening Chameleons with a Black Hole
column27: It is believed that the additional degrees of freedom in any modification of gravity are screened by the matter densities coexisting in an astrophysical Black Hole. In this talk, we find that this might not always be the case.

Signatures of Horndeski's Gravity on ultra-large cosmic scales
Testing gravity with X-ray polarization from accreting black holes
column27: X-ray polarimetry will open a new observational window on black holes. It will provide us with information on thegeometry of the emission region with unprecedented resolution, allowing us to probe strong gravity in black holes' accretion disks.

column26: Potential tests of Quantum Gravity
column27: Most quantum gravity theories predict the Generalized Uncertainty Principle (GUP) to replace the Heisenberg principle near the Planck scale. We show that GUP in turn predicts potentially observable quantum gravity effects in quantum optical systems.

column27: We study causal structure and shock formation in Horndeski theory and its generalization to two scalar fields. We find that shock formation may occur for gravitational wave in these theories. (Full abstract sent to testing-gravity-2017@sfu.ca)

column27: Planck 2015 data shows a possible scale dependent local Non-Gaussianity. I will show how such feature is naturally achieved if tensor modes significantly contribute to primordial NG. This is possible in a space-time symmetry breaking theory.

column26: Testing gravity with E_G: Mapping theory onto observation
column27: The cosmological statistic E_G tests gravity by combining weak lensing, galaxy clustering, and redshift-space distortions. I will discuss the impact and mitigation of theoretical uncertainties affecting E_G, and its relevance for future surveys.

column7: Dept. of Physics, Univ. of Arizona
column18: Department of Physics, University of Arizona
column26: Inequality between Inertial and Gravitational Masses: Suggested Experiment on the Earth’s Orbit
column27: We theoretically discuss some novel possible experiment on theEarth's orbit. If such experiment is done, it will be the first direct observation of quantum effects in the General Relativity.

column26: f(R,DµR,…,Dµ1…DµnR) theories of gravity and the equivalence with scalar-multi-tensorial theories.
column27: f(R,DµR,…,Dµ1…DµnR) theories of gravity are proven to be equivalent to scalar-multi-tensorial theories. This result can be seen as an extension of the equivalence between f(R) and Brans-Dicke theories.

column26: Testing cosmic parity violation with CMB 2, 3, 4 point-correlators
column27: Under the existence of chiral sources, such as a vector field coupled to an axion, primordial correlators break parity. I introduce interesting signatures of induced CMB 2, 3, 4-point correlators, and their current and future constraints.

column26: Modification to Newtonian gravity of two types of opposite masses
column27: The model assigns Coulombic gravitational interaction to dark matter and baryonic particles, where like masses repel and unlike masses attract. It provides a physical explanation to MOND theory and explains flat rotation curves for spiral galaxies.

column26: Testing local Lorentz invariance with gravitational waves
column27: Following a review of the framework for testing local Lorentz invariance provided by the gravitational Standard-Model Extension, applications to gravitational-wave related searches will be discussed.

column26: What do GW150914 and GW151226 tell us about extreme gravity?
column27: aLIGO's discovery of the direct detection of gravitational waves allow us to probe gravity in extreme gravity for the first time. I will describe how well GW150914 and GW151226 probe fundamental pillars of General Relativity and current limitations.

column26: Cosmology with bigravity theory
column27: As an infrared modification of gravity, we discuss dRGT bigravity theory, focusing on if it can consistently explain cosmological evolution both in early time and in late time. We also discuss fluctuations generated during inflation in bigravity.

column26: Testing the equivalence principle with macroscopic atom interferometers
column27: Matter wave interferometers that cover macroscopic scales in space and in time have a high intrinsic sensitivity to inertial forces.  We show how such interferometers can be used in a dual configuration for a test of the weak equivalence principle.

column26: Cosmology in generalized Proca theories
column27: We study the cosmology in the presence of a massive vector field with derivative interactions that propagates only the 3 desired polarizations with second-order equations of motion.

column26: Observing GR effect and mass of the massive BH at the center of our galaxy: GR calculation and Subaru telescopce observation

column26: Cosmological consistency tests of gravity theory and cosmic acceleration
column27: Testing general relativity at cosmological scales and probing the cause of cosmic acceleration are among the important objectives targeted by incoming and future astronomical surveys and experiments. I present our recent results on consistency tests

column26: Gravitational waves from protoneutron stars
column27: We systematically examine the oscillation frequencies of protoneutron star after core-bounce and find an universal relation of the frequencies of the fundamental oscillations, which is independent of the progenitor models.

column26: Testing black hole ringdowns with gravitational waves
Testing gravity with E_G: Mapping theory onto observation
column27: The cosmological statistic E_G tests gravity by combining weak lensing, galaxy clustering, and redshift-space distortions. I will discuss the impact and mitigation of theoretical uncertainties affecting E_G, and its relevance for future surveys.

column26: Probing Dark Energy with the Canadian Hydrogen Intensity Mapping Experiment (CHIME)
column27: CHIME is a transit radio interferometer designed specifically for probing dark energy. I will discuss its goals, its status and describe the powerful new analysis techniques we have developed to confront the many challenges of such observations.
